displaytitle: Seated Madonna and Child and Various Studies
medium: Pen and brown ink and brush and brown wash on light tan laid paper; verso: Pen and brown ink, brush and brown wash, and red chalk, on light tan laid paper
creditline: Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt, Class of 1895
markings: Watermark: Crossed arrows with six-pointed star; cf. Briquet 6299 (Augsburg 1554)

titles.title: Seated Madonna and Child and Various Studies

texts.textentryhtml:
Handwritten note: Attribution changed in Italian Drawing Show, 1966.  Former attribution by T.P.B. to Parmagianino.;

 Attributed to Jacopo Bertoja by Konrad Oberhuber in “Albertina Studien”. (See reference Bib. );

Recto: During his brief career, the painter Jacopo Bertoia worked primarily for the Farnese family, executing decorative projects for their palaces in Parma and Caprarola (outside Rome). His virtuoso and lyrical draftsmanship is captured on this double-sided sheet in a flurry of sketches, none of which relate precisely to any of the artist’s known religious or secular commissions. On the recto, the dramatic tonality of the central Madonna and Child is offset by the calligraphic angels and reclining figures.

Verso: Amid this group of sketches, the most unusual are the two heads in the lower left corner. Bertoia was either looking at living individuals with unusual features or exaggerating specific characteristics for comic effect—as in the small black chalk caricature in Michelangelo’s drawing on view nearby.
